Numuse Documentation

Welcome to Numuse’s documentation!

Welcome to Numuse’s documentation!¶

Wecome to Numuse, this is a package for analyzing musical ideas and testing out conjectures about what makes certain ideas sound good.

To get started with the notation please watch my introductory video

Contents:

  • Installation
  • Support
  • Abbreviations

Reference Manual¶

The pages linked to here are currently a work in progress.

Notation¶

class notation.NoteCollection(notes: set)¶

A collection of notes from a musical system

notes: List[int]

the notes in this note collection

__eq__(other_NC: NoteCollection)

Checks whether this note collection is the same as the other one

generate_wave_function(self)

Generates the wave function determined by the current musical system As of right now this is assumed to be 12 tone equal temperament

compute_diatonic_distance(self, other_NC: NoteCollection):

Return how many notes the two note collections differ by

compute_diatonic_distance(other_NC: notation.NoteCollection) → float¶

Return how many notes the two note collections differ by

class notation.RootedIntervalCollection(root: int, interval_collection: Set[int], duration=0, musical_system=<musical_system.RBMS_Approximation object>)¶

A note collection instantiated in a special way

A rooted interval collection is a way to define a set of notes of a musical system.

It does so specifying a note (denoted by root) from the system and a set of intervals measured with respect to the root.

generate_interval_to_occurance() → Dict[int, int]¶

Generate a dictionary that maps all possible intervals in this interval collection to the number of times it appears

generate_notes(root, interval_collection) → Set[int]¶

Generate the notes that are defined by taking the root note and adding the notes in the interval collection

get_fundamental_representation() → notation.RootedIntervalCollection¶

Generate the fundamental representation of this interval collection

The fundamental representation a rooted interval collection where the interval are within the range 0 … num_notes - 1 where num_notes is defined by the musical system we are dealing with.

In 12 tone equal temperament, num_notes is equal to 12.

Example:

If we have a rooted interval collection 13 | -3 1 2 24

Tools¶

tools.I(x: int, y: int) → int¶

Return the interval between the two notes x, y

xint

The first note

yint

The second note

The interval between x and y

tools.ranged_modulus_operator(x: int, m: int) → int¶

Return what x is congruent to in the range 0 … m-1

xint

The number to be analyzed

mint

The modulus

The unique number from 0 to m-1 (inclusive) that x is congruent to
